etymologies: Middle English (in the sense ‘move suddenly aside’): perhaps from shun

definitions: push or pull (a train or part of a train) from the main line to a siding or from one line of rails to another

examples.text: their train had been shunted into a siding

notes.text: with object and adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: push or pull train or part of train from main line to siding or from one line of rails to another

examples.text: chairs were being shunted to and fro

definitions: direct or divert to a less important place or position

examples.text: amateurs were gradually being shunted to filing jobs

shortDefinitions: direct or divert to less important place or position

definitions: provide (an electrical current) with a conductor joining two points of a circuit, through which more or less of the current may be diverted

examples.text: these components are designed to shunt electrical surges away from microcircuits

shortDefinitions: provide electrical current with conductor joining two points of circuit

definitions: an act of pushing or shoving something

examples.text: the engine turnround was helped by a gravity shunt
the car would turn into a fireball when hit by even quite gentle shunts

shortDefinitions: act of pushing or shoving something

definitions: a motor accident, especially a collision of vehicles travelling one close behind the other

examples.text: a lorry shed its load, causing an eight-vehicle shunt

definitions: an electrical conductor joining two points of a circuit, through which more or less of a current may be diverted.
shortDefinitions: electrical conductor joining two points of circuit

definitions: an alternative path for the passage of the blood or other body fluid
shortDefinitions: alternative path for passage of blood
